speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: SCENE I. Rome. BRUTUS's orchard.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Enter BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What, Lucius, ho!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I cannot, by the progress of the stars,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give guess how near to day. Lucius, I say!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I would it were my fault to sleep so soundly.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When, Lucius, when? awake, I say! what, Lucius!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Call'd you, my lord?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get me a taper in my study, Lucius:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When it is lighted, come and call me here.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I will, my lord.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It must be by his death: and for my part,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I know no personal cause to spurn at him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But for the general. He would be crown'd:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How that might change his nature, there's the question.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is the bright day that brings forth the adder;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And that craves wary walking. Crown him?--that;--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And then, I grant, we put a sting in him,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That at his will he may do danger with.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The abuse of greatness is, when it disjoins

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Remorse from power: and, to speak truth of Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have not known when his affections sway'd

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: More than his reason. But 'tis a common proof,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That lowliness is young ambition's ladder,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Whereto the climber-upward turns his face;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But when he once attains the upmost round.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He then unto the ladder turns his back,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Looks in the clouds, scorning the base degrees

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By which he did ascend. So Caesar may.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Then, lest he may, prevent. And, since the quarrel

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Will bear no colour for the thing he is,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fashion it thus; that what he is, augmented,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Would run to these and these extremities:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And therefore think him as a serpent's egg

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which, hatch'd, would, as his kind, grow mischievous,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And kill him in the shell.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: The taper burneth in your closet, sir.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Searching the window for a flint, I found

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: This paper, thus seal'd up; and, I am sure,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: It did not lie there when I went to bed.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Gives him the letter

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get you to bed again; it is not day.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is not to-morrow, boy, the ides of March?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I know not, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Look in the calendar, and bring me word.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: I will, sir.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The exhalations whizzing in the air

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give so much light that I may read by them.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Opens the letter and reads

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake, and see thyself.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall Rome,  and c. Speak, strike, redress!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Brutus, thou sleep'st: awake!'

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Such instigations have been often dropp'd

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where I have took them up.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Shall Rome,  and c.' Thus must I piece it out:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall Rome stand under one man's awe? What, Rome?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: My ancestors did from the streets of Rome

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The Tarquin drive, when he was call'd a king.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Speak, strike, redress!' Am I entreated

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To speak and strike? O Rome, I make thee promise:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If the redress will follow, thou receivest

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thy full petition at the hand of Brutus!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sir, March is wasted fourteen days.

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: 'Tis good. Go to the gate; somebody knocks.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Since Cassius first did whet me against Caesar,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have not slept.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Between the acting of a dreadful thing

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And the first motion, all the interim is

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Like a phantasma, or a hideous dream:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The Genius and the mortal instruments

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Are then in council; and the state of man,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Like to a little kingdom, suffers then

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The nature of an insurrection.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Sir, 'tis your brother Cassius at the door,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: Who doth desire to see you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is he alone?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No, sir, there are moe with him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Do you know them?

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: No, sir; their hats are pluck'd about their ears,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: And half their faces buried in their cloaks,

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: That by no means I may discover them

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: By any mark of favour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let 'em enter.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit LUCIUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They are the faction. O conspiracy,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Shamest thou to show thy dangerous brow by night,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When evils are most free? O, then by day

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Where wilt thou find a cavern dark enough

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To mask thy monstrous visage? Seek none, conspiracy;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hide it in smiles and affability:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For if thou path, thy native semblance on,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not Erebus itself were dim enough

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To hide thee from prevention.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter the conspirators, CASSIUS, CASCA, DECIUS BRUTUS, CINNA, METELLUS CIMBER, and TREBONIUS

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I think we are too bold upon your rest:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Good morrow, Brutus; do we trouble you?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I have been up this hour, awake all night.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Know I these men that come along with you?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Yes, every man of them, and no man here

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But honours you; and every one doth wish

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: You had but that opinion of yourself

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Which every noble Roman bears of you.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This is Trebonius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is welcome hither.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This, Decius Brutus.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He is welcome too.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: This, Casca; this, Cinna; and this, Metellus Cimber.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They are all welcome.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What watchful cares do interpose themselves

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Betwixt your eyes and night?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Shall I entreat a word?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: BRUTUS and CASSIUS whisper

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Here lies the east: doth not the day break here?

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: No.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: O, pardon, sir, it doth; and yon gray lines

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: That fret the clouds are messengers of day.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: You shall confess that you are both deceived.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Here, as I point my sword, the sun arises,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Which is a great way growing on the south,

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Weighing the youthful season of the year.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Some two months hence up higher toward the north

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: He first presents his fire; and the high east

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Stands, as the Capitol, directly here.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Give me your hands all over, one by one.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And let us swear our resolution.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No, not an oath: if not the face of men,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The sufferance of our souls, the time's abuse,--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If these be motives weak, break off betimes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And every man hence to his idle bed;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: So let high-sighted tyranny range on,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Till each man drop by lottery. But if these,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As I am sure they do, bear fire enough

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To kindle cowards and to steel with valour

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The melting spirits of women, then, countrymen,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: What need we any spur but our own cause,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To prick us to redress? what other bond

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than secret Romans, that have spoke the word,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And will not palter? and what other oath

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than honesty to honesty engaged,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That this shall be, or we will fall for it?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Swear priests and cowards and men cautelous,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Old feeble carrions and such suffering souls

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That welcome wrongs; unto bad causes swear

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Such creatures as men doubt; but do not stain

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The even virtue of our enterprise,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Nor the insuppressive mettle of our spirits,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To think that or our cause or our performance

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Did need an oath; when every drop of blood

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That every Roman bears, and nobly bears,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is guilty of a several bastardy,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If he do break the smallest particle

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of any promise that hath pass'd from him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But what of Cicero? shall we sound him?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: I think he will stand very strong with us.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Let us not leave him out.

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: No, by no means.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: O, let us have him, for his silver hairs

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Will purchase us a good opinion

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: And buy men's voices to commend our deeds:

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: It shall be said, his judgment ruled our hands;

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Our youths and wildness shall no whit appear,

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: But all be buried in his gravity.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, name him not: let us not break with him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For he will never follow any thing

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That other men begin.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Then leave him out.

speaker: CASCA
text_entry: Indeed he is not fit.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Shall no man else be touch'd but only Caesar?

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Decius, well urged: I think it is not meet,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Mark Antony, so well beloved of Caesar,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Should outlive Caesar: we shall find of him

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: A shrewd contriver; and, you know, his means,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: If he improve them, may well stretch so far

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: As to annoy us all: which to prevent,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Let Antony and Caesar fall together.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our course will seem too bloody, Caius Cassius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To cut the head off and then hack the limbs,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Like wrath in death and envy afterwards;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For Antony is but a limb of Caesar:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let us be sacrificers, but not butchers, Caius.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We all stand up against the spirit of Caesar;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And in the spirit of men there is no blood:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, that we then could come by Caesar's spirit,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And not dismember Caesar! But, alas,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caesar must bleed for it! And, gentle friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let's kill him boldly, but not wrathfully;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let's carve him as a dish fit for the gods,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Not hew him as a carcass fit for hounds:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And let our hearts, as subtle masters do,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Stir up their servants to an act of rage,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And after seem to chide 'em. This shall make

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Our purpose necessary and not envious:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which so appearing to the common eyes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We shall be call'd purgers, not murderers.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And for Mark Antony, think not of him;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: For he can do no more than Caesar's arm

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When Caesar's head is off.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Yet I fear him;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For in the ingrafted love he bears to Caesar--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Alas, good Cassius, do not think of him:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If he love Caesar, all that he can do

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Is to himself, take thought and die for Caesar:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And that were much he should; for he is given

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To sports, to wildness and much company.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: There is no fear in him; let him not die;

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: For he will live, and laugh at this hereafter.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: Clock strikes

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Peace! count the clock.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The clock hath stricken three.

speaker: TREBONIUS
text_entry: 'Tis time to part.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: But it is doubtful yet,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Whether Caesar will come forth to-day, or no;

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: For he is superstitious grown of late,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Quite from the main opinion he held once

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Of fantasy, of dreams and ceremonies:

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: It may be, these apparent prodigies,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The unaccustom'd terror of this night,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And the persuasion of his augurers,

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: May hold him from the Capitol to-day.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Never fear that: if he be so resolved,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: I can o'ersway him; for he loves to hear

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: That unicorns may be betray'd with trees,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And bears with glasses, elephants with holes,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Lions with toils and men with flatterers;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: But when I tell him he hates flatterers,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: He says he does, being then most flattered.

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: Let me work;

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: For I can give his humour the true bent,

speaker: DECIUS BRUTUS
text_entry: And I will bring him to the Capitol.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: Nay, we will all of us be there to fetch him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: By the eighth hour: is that the uttermost?

speaker: CINNA
text_entry: Be that the uttermost, and fail not then.

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Caius Ligarius doth bear Caesar hard,

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: Who rated him for speaking well of Pompey:

speaker: METELLUS CIMBER
text_entry: I wonder none of you have thought of him.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Now, good Metellus, go along by him:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He loves me well, and I have given him reasons;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Send him but hither, and I'll fashion him.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: The morning comes upon 's: we'll leave you, Brutus.

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: And, friends, disperse yourselves; but all remember

speaker: CASSIUS
text_entry: What you have said, and show yourselves true Romans.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Good gentlemen, look fresh and merrily;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let not our looks put on our purposes,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But bear it as our Roman actors do,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With untired spirits and formal constancy:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And so good morrow to you every one.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt all but BRUTUS

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Boy! Lucius! Fast asleep? It is no matter;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enjoy the honey-heavy dew of slumber:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Thou hast no figures nor no fantasies,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Which busy care draws in the brains of men;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Therefore thou sleep'st so sound.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter PORTIA

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Brutus, my lord!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Portia, what mean you? wherefore rise you now?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: It is not for your health thus to commit

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Your weak condition to the raw cold morning.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Nor for yours neither. You've ungently, Brutus,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Stole from my bed: and yesternight, at supper,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You suddenly arose, and walk'd about,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Musing and sighing, with your arms across,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And when I ask'd you what the matter was,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You stared upon me with ungentle looks;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I urged you further; then you scratch'd your head,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And too impatiently stamp'd with your foot;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Yet I insisted, yet you answer'd not,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But, with an angry wafture of your hand,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Gave sign for me to leave you: so I did;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Fearing to strengthen that impatience

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which seem'd too much enkindled, and withal

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Hoping it was but an effect of humour,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which sometime hath his hour with every man.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: It will not let you eat, nor talk, nor sleep,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And could it work so much upon your shape

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: As it hath much prevail'd on your condition,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I should not know you, Brutus. Dear my lord,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Make me acquainted with your cause of grief.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I am not well in health, and that is all.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Brutus is wise, and, were he not in health,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: He would embrace the means to come by it.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Why, so I do. Good Portia, go to bed.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is Brutus sick? and is it physical

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To walk unbraced and suck up the humours

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of the dank morning? What, is Brutus sick,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And will he steal out of his wholesome bed,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To dare the vile contagion of the night

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And tempt the rheumy and unpurged air

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To add unto his sickness? No, my Brutus;

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: You have some sick offence within your mind,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which, by the right and virtue of my place,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I ought to know of: and, upon my knees,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I charm you, by my once-commended beauty,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: By all your vows of love and that great vow

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Which did incorporate and make us one,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That you unfold to me, yourself, your half,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Why you are heavy, and what men to-night

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Have had to resort to you: for here have been

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Some six or seven, who did hide their faces

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Even from darkness.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Kneel not, gentle Portia.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I should not need, if you were gentle Brutus.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Within the bond of marriage, tell me, Brutus,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Is it excepted I should know no secrets

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: That appertain to you? Am I yourself

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: But, as it were, in sort or limitation,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: To keep with you at meals, comfort your bed,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And talk to you sometimes? Dwell I but in the suburbs

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Of your good pleasure? If it be no more,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Portia is Brutus' harlot, not his wife.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: You are my true and honourable wife,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As dear to me as are the ruddy drops

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That visit my sad heart

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: If this were true, then should I know this secret.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I grant I am a woman; but withal

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A woman that Lord Brutus took to wife:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I grant I am a woman; but withal

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: A woman well-reputed, Cato's daughter.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Think you I am no stronger than my sex,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Being so father'd and so husbanded?

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Tell me your counsels, I will not disclose 'em:

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: I have made strong proof of my constancy,

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Giving myself a voluntary wound

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: Here, in the thigh: can I bear that with patience.

speaker: PORTIA
text_entry: And not my husband's secrets?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O ye gods,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Render me worthy of this noble wife!

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Knocking within

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Hark, hark! one knocks: Portia, go in awhile;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And by and by thy bosom shall partake

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The secrets of my heart.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: All my engagements I will construe to thee,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: All the charactery of my sad brows:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Leave me with haste.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exit PORTIA

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lucius, who's that knocks?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter LUCIUS with LIGARIUS

speaker: LUCIUS
text_entry: He is a sick man that would speak with you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Caius Ligarius, that Metellus spake of.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Boy, stand aside. Caius Ligarius! how?

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Vouchsafe good morrow from a feeble tongue.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: O, what a time have you chose out, brave Caius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To wear a kerchief! Would you were not sick!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: I am not sick, if Brutus have in hand

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Any exploit worthy the name of honour.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Such an exploit have I in hand, Ligarius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Had you a healthful ear to hear of it.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: By all the gods that Romans bow before,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: I here discard my sickness! Soul of Rome!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Brave son, derived from honourable loins!

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Thou, like an exorcist, hast conjured up

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: My mortified spirit. Now bid me run,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: And I will strive with things impossible;

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Yea, get the better of them. What's to do?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A piece of work that will make sick men whole.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: But are not some whole that we must make sick?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That must we also. What it is, my Caius,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I shall unfold to thee, as we are going

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: To whom it must be done.

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: Set on your foot,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: And with a heart new-fired I follow you,

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: To do I know not what: but it sufficeth

speaker: LIGARIUS
text_entry: That Brutus leads me on.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Follow me, then.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Exeunt
